description: From Middle English somouns (“order or command to do something”), borrowed from Old French sumunce (modern French semonce), from Vulgar Latin *summonsa, a noun use of the feminine past participle of summoneō, summonēre (“to summon”).

entries.meaning: A call to do something, especially to come.
(law) A notice summoning someone to appear in court, as a defendant, juror or witness.

verbs.description: summons (third-person singular simple present summonses, present participle summonsing, simple past and past participle summonsed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To serve someone with a summons. [17th C.]

description: See the etymology of the corresponding lemma form.

entries.meaning: third-person singular simple present indicative form of summon
